comments.commentBody:
"hold him accountable for adhering to the best of what America is"

How can Trump - or anyone else, for that matter - be held "accountable for adhering to the best of what America is" is something that he's _not_ doing
Trump allegedly won the Electoral College vote? Yes, it is confirmed, And yes he will be President.

How is this comment a Times pick?  The majority of Americans do not agree based on the popular vote.  Also, pointing out the virulent racism of someone in the White House is not name calling.  Seriously will the Times stop at nothing to perpetuate the scourge of false equivalency?  This is getting ridiculous.

There is a whole article on his inappropriate comments on the front page. Good grief! The guy is a hater. Look up the Aug 25 copy of The Atlantic article by Conor Friedersdorf  on how Bannon is not even a conservative- he just wants to burn the country down.

Heads must be exploding from all the hard and deep thinking that must have gone in to alleging racism against the incumbent administration less than a week after the election. It hardly matters whether Bannon is a racist, or is not a racist, or is any of the other things that have been rumored about him. He has been called a racist on the front page of the New York Times. Damage done!

All this assumes, however, that such a response never crossed the minds of the incoming leadership.

It will be interesting to see what happens next.
Thing is, Bannon IS a Racist. And it DOES MATTER!

Are you kidding? Bannon made no secret of this stuff.- Did you miss the year long campaign of Trump? lol

The KKK and Neo Nazi sites were welcome there. It has been going on for a long time.

And so it begins…

Oh, let’s not “personally offend” Kellyanne Conway—that delicate flower who projectile-vomited atrocious lies about Hillary Clinton faster than the mind could process them 24/7 throughout the election—or Conway might deny us access to Trump. (Yet access to Trump will get you what?) That line wasn't a throwaway, she says nothing the Trump/Mercer braintrust don't devise in advance.

Both Kellyanne Conway and Steve Bannon were until recently (?) employed by New York hedge fund billionaire Robert Mercer, Conway running his Ted Cruz SuperPAC and Bannon running his Breitbart site.

Mercer also just happens to be principal investor in Cambridge Analytica, the big-data firm that targets voters based on their psychological profiles. Gee, ya think? Cambridge was Trump's pollster, so some of Mercer's tens of millions in donations to Trump have already found their way back home.

Cambridge Analytica's previous success was the Brexit campaign, which Mercer won by ginning up the racist nationalist turnout, furthered by Breitbart's UK site. Mercer funds similar nationalist movements in France, Italy and elsewhere.

Mercer's a tax evader ($7 billion) who wants to abolish the IRS. He funds climate denial and wants John Bolton as Secretary of State.

Trump fans who think they're getting unadulterated Trump and voted against the candidate they are told was corrupt and in favor of a "global world order" may be surprised to learn we're getting that on a scale we've never seen.
Wish you were wrong but you're not. It's the axis of evil we that was the other guy. Where is Edward Snowden when you need him!
Excellent research!

Is it true that the transition team asked for Top Secret clearance for the "kids"? I worked in CIC, Combat Information Center on a ship in Vietnam. Things have changed, I guess. In those days, there was a thing called "need to know". The kids can run the company with a little inside info from the secret stuff. Bannon as official press censor can keep it under wraps. If any of the kids spill their guts, blame it on Hillary. Perfect.

Look on the bright side. Such a situation, lots of conflicts of interests, might be a reason to impeach Trump.
Then we can get on with business as usual under President Mike Pence.

It is true that any agency of the United States Federal Government is obliged to comply with presidential requests for classified information, and Trump has not and will not be vetted for a security clearance because the election gave him the keys to everything.
Please, I'm beggin' ya. Give us some evidence of your claim.

Before President Obama took office the GOP leadership/establishment has already schemed to undermine and block his initiatives, even stating for the record their job was to make him a one-term president. During both his presidential campaigns, he did not speak disparagingly of any organization, ethnic, racial, or religious group or threaten them via proposed policies. Yet  this president-elect has done just the opposite throughout his campaign—threaten and disparage any one who is not a white heterosexual male. And we are being asked to give him a chance? Really? Attacks on President Obama and Secretary Clinton were relentless (from birthers, patriotism,religion, whitewater, e-mails ... ) and now we are supposed to lighten up? Forgive? Move on? I don't think so. We have come too far to Make. America. Great. Again.
Gosh, all of Trump's "pals" have made racist comments! What a surprise!

The alt-right are gestapo wannabees.

Rick Wilson's characterization is right on the mark,; the one with childless single men and anime ... that's a bit too 'eeeuw' to put here in the comments.

What's so depressing is the fact that Trump's groping is NOT a bug, it's a feature. Look at the evidence --Trump's people are pro-groping ... the women included.

Yeah, imagine that anyone might question Trump's fitness to be President? Today he called Putin and it was a love fest. He could hear the sincerity in Putin's voice and he could fathom Putin's soul. It's that kind of incautious behavior that creates problems for all but nobody seems to have told Trump to do his homework before speaking with another person serving as a head of state. But he has such a good brain, there must have been some genius to what he did.
I hope the members of the electoral college value the lives of their children and grandchildren.  It's not too late to stop this horrible downhill slide.

So I guess we'd wish our president to be sitting in a room full of strangers that he has no desire to listen to whenever he makes a decision?  He may as well go sit in a Starbucks when he does and forget the staff.

If Don Trump appoints Giuliani Attorney General, we can expect martial law in America as Trump implied by innuendo during his nomination acceptance speech. Everyone in New York knows Giuliani loves a fascist police-state.
Paul Wolfowitz and Donald Rumsfeld are still around.
Majority did you say?  What majority?

"Throwing around racism and anti-antisemitism and white nationalism in every Trump article leaves the rest of the article lacking in force and delivery."

"Throwing around racism and anti-antisemitism and white nationalism in every Trump article leaves the rest of the article lacking in force and delivery."

No, it doesn't, Adeel.

"Please do better to report accurate information"

Is information inaccurate because someone chooses not to believe it? If so, then, since I don't even believe the punctuation, the "information" at Breitbart is, by definition, inaccurate. Do you agree, Adeel?

"What forces and strains in America drove this divisive election and outcome?"
Seriously? Anybody outside the coastal bubble was anxious that this was a real possibility. The Times needed to actually be in "America" for most the election to have had an even rudimentary understanding of what's been going on. That's called reporting, on the ground real-time reporting. And you didn't do it. The publisher's letter ain't gonna cut it. Do better. Starting today. Have some guts, spend more money on on-the-ground news gathering. You can do it.

I'm starting to look elsewhere. In the meantime, a bit of advice: make the online reader purposely navigate to commentary — just like the old days of paper and TV when commentary and news were very separate.

My college science journalism professor was a former editor of the NYT who taught us the of the Gray Lady’s journalistic integrity. In the 90s, the NYT studied the most popular article types and topics; naturally, my professor asked to see her reader’s preferences. She was told no; the NYT’s editors are professionals of the highest caliber, and they were trusted to print what they considered newsworthy, not cater to readers’ preferences. I’ve recently become very painfully aware of my personal echo chamber, that my social media network of friends and acquaintances are not representative of the national and global community in which I live. At the same time, responsible journalism includes all sides of a story, but often irresponsible journalism tries to cover them all equally. It’s a difficult balance, but it’s one I hope to see achieved.
In an era of buzzfeed and facebook, the free press has come under immense pressure. I’ve decided that the only way forward is to disable my adblockers and sign up for a dead tree subscription of the NYT, rallying behind the courageous paper of record behind the Pentagon Papers and New York Times Co. v. Sullivan.

It is hard to see the future and you folks do a good job of trying to have a crystal ball. One angle that I'd like to see more of is the changing picture of the country as we rapidly become more diverse. The red vs the blue paradigm is fine but I'd like to see how that works as the younger, more diverse America is coming to the fore. The prevailing wisdom is that voters become more conservative as they get older. Does that belief apply across all racial, ethnic and geographical groups. How does it play out for the future Electoral College maps?
The country needs you more than ever. Bannon in the White House is all anyone who values American pluralism needs to know. A free and honest press is the hard line between fascism and freedom.

if this is your response to the NYTimes pledge, you cannot possibly have read the NYTimes coverage for the past 6 months.  Either that, or you are a Sanders supporter.  Either way, blaming the NYTimes for the election of a "proto fascist" (and I agree with that characterization) is the very paradigm of shooting the messenger.  The NYTimes is right to rededicate itself - we need stellar reporting & investigative journalism NOW more than EVER.  I'm not going to cancel my subscription; if I thought it'd help, I subscribe twice.

This comment could be applied to many media outlets, both print & television & radio.  All this emphasis on Clinton's emails, provided to us by the Russians & wikileaks, when you could have been spending ten times as much coverage on the many problems of Donald Trump's actions, conflicts of interests, racism, etc.  Even today, where's the focus on Steve Bannon, a prominent white nationalist, and the many conflicts of interest between Trump's companies, Trump's children in possibly being involved in his companies & his administration, & getting to the bottom of Trump's international loans & areas where he could be vulnerable to blackmail-like persuasion.   If there's one thing we've learned about Donald Trump in the past year, it's that his top priority is coming out on top, regardless of damage done to people who work for him or invest in his companies.  So I think it's reasonable to say he would sell out the American people or doing what is in the best interest of the United States in order to do what is best for him or his company.

I think you and many other media entities need to figure out how not to be manipulated by the candidates and their teams.  When Donald Trump would say something shocking or outrageous on Twitter or in a speech, it seems that most media sources would repeat it over and over again, serving as the perfect amplifier and repeater.  It is not right for the media to give any candidate huge amounts of free publicity, and policies and protocols need to be put in place to avoid this manipulation.

Senator Sanders wasn't defeated by the media, especially the NYTimes that was at pains to treat him fairly.  I voted for Senator Sanders, and even i acknowledge that he was beaten fairly in a fair process by millions of Democratic & independent voters who preferred Secretary Clinton as the Democratic nominee.
